In addition to traditional course materials such as a filmed lecture, readings and problem sets, many MOOCs provide interactive user forums to support community interactions.

WikiResult.title: Massive open online course
WikiResult.abstract: A massive open online course (MOOC /muk/) is an online course aimed at unlimited participation and open access via the web. In addition to traditional course materials such as filmed lectures, readings, and problem sets, many MOOCs provide interactive user forums to support community interactions among students, professors, and teaching assistants (TAs). MOOCs are a recent and widely researched development in distance education which were first introduced in 2008 and emerged as a popular mode of learning in 2012. Early MOOCs often emphasized open-access features, such as open licensing of content, structure and learning goals, to promote the reuse and remixing of resources. Some later MOOCs use closed licenses for their course materials while maintaining free access for students. Robert Zemsky (2014) argues that they have passed their peak: "They came; they conquered very little; and now they face substantially diminished prospects."
WikiResult.summary: A massive open online course (MOOC /muk/) is an online course aimed at unlimited participation and open access via the web. In addition to traditional course materials such as filmed lectures, readings, and problem sets, many MOOCs provide interactive user forums to support community interactions among students, professors, and teaching assistants (TAs). MOOCs are a recent and widely researched development in distance education which were first introduced in 2008 and emerged as a popular mode of learning in 2012.

WikiResult.title: Podcast
WikiResult.summary: A podcast is a form of digital media that consists of an episodic series of audio, video, digital radio, PDF, or ePub files subscribed to and downloaded through web syndication or streamed online to a computer or mobile device. The word is a portmanteau of "(i)Pod" and "broadcast."The Merriam Webster Tenth International Collegiate defines "podcast" as: a program (as of music or talk) made available in digital format for automatic download over the Internet.
WikiResult.abstract: A podcast is a form of digital media that consists of an episodic series of audio, video, digital radio, PDF, or ePub files subscribed to and downloaded through web syndication or streamed online to a computer or mobile device. The word is a portmanteau of "(i)Pod" and "broadcast." The Merriam Webster Tenth International Collegiate defines "podcast" as: a program (as of music or talk) made available in digital format for automatic download over the Internet. A podcast's distributor maintains a list of audio or video files in a series on a server as a web feed, and the listener or viewer uses special client application software, known as a podcatcher, to access this web feed, check it for updates, and download any new files in the series. This process can be automated so that new files are downloaded automatically, which may seem to the user as if the content is being broadcast or "pushed" to them. Files are stored locally on the user's computer or other device, ready for offline use. Podcasting contrasts with webcasting (Internet streaming), which generally isn't designed for offline listening to user-selected content. As discussed by Richard Berry, podcasting is both a converged medium bringing together audio, the web, and portable media player, and a disruptive technology that has caused some in the radio business to reconsider established practices and preconceptions about audiences, consumption, production, and distribution. This is largely because no one person owns the technology; it is free to listen and create content, which departs from the traditional model of "gate-kept" media and production tools. It is very much a horizontal media form: producers are consumers and consumers become producers and engage in conversations with each other.

WikiResult.abstract: Crowdfunding is the practice of funding a project or venture by raising monetary contributions from a large number of people, today often performed via internet-mediated registries, but the concept can also be executed through mail-order subscriptions, benefit events, and other methods. Crowdfunding is a form of alternative finance, which has emerged outside of the traditional financial system. The crowdfunding model is based on three types of actors: the project initiator who proposes the idea and/or project to be funded; individuals or groups who support the idea; and a moderating organization (the "platform") that brings the parties together to launch the idea . In 2013, the crowdfunding industry raised over $5.1 billion worldwide.

technologies.Description: As a maker becomes more of an entrepreneur, equity crowdfuding platform allows to find investement money for equity into the startup company. Ex: Seedrs, fundedbyme...

WikiResult.abstract: Equity crowdfunding is the online offering of private company securities to a group of people for investment. Because equity crowdfunding involves investment into a commercial enterprise, it is often subject to securities and financial regulation. Equity crowdfunding is also referred to as crowdinvesting, investment crowdfunding, or crowd equity. Equity crowdfunding is a mechanism that enables broad groups of investors to fund startup companies and small businesses in return for equity. Investors give money to a business and receive ownership of a small piece of that business. If the business succeeds, then its value goes up, as well as the value of a share in that businessthe converse is also true. Coverage of equity crowdfunding indicates that its potential is greatest with startup businesses that are seeking smaller investments to achieve establishment, while follow-on funding (required for subsequent growth) may come from other sources.
WikiResult.title: Equity crowdfunding

WikiResult.abstract: Virtual reality (VR) typically refers to computer technologies that use software to generate realistic images, sounds and other sensations that replicate a real environment (or create an imaginary setting), and simulate a user's physical presence in this environment, by enabling the user to interact with this space and any objects depicted therein using specialized display screens or projectors and other devices. VR has been defined as "...a realistic and immersive simulation of a three-dimensional environment, created using interactive software and hardware, and experienced or controlled by movement of the body" or as an "immersive, interactive experience generated by a computer". A person using virtual reality equipment is typically able to "look around" the artificial world, move about in it and interact with features or items that are depicted on a screen or in goggles. Virtual realities artificially create sensory experiences, which can include sight, touch, hearing, and, less commonly, smell. Most 2016-era virtual realities are displayed either on a computer monitor, a projector screen, or with a virtual reality headset (also called head-mounted display or HMD). HMDs typically take the form of head-mounted goggles with a screen in front of the eyes. Some simulations include additional sensory information and provide sounds through speakers or headphones.Virtual Reality actually brings the user into the digital world by cutting off outside stimuli. In this way user is solely focusing on the digital content. Some advanced haptic systems in the 2010s now include tactile information, generally known as force feedback in medical, video gaming and military training applications. Some VR systems used in video games can transmit vibrations and other sensations to the user via the game controller. Virtual reality also refers to remote communication environments which provide a virtual presence of users with through telepresence and telexistence or the use of a virtual artifact (VA), either through the use of standard input devices such as a keyboard and mouse, or through multimodal devices such as a wired glove or omnidirectional treadmills. The immersive environment can be similar to the real world in order to create a lifelike experiencefor example, in simulations for pilot or combat training, which depict realistic images and sounds of the world, where the normal laws of physics apply (e.g., in flight simulators), or it can differ significantly from reality, such as in VR video games that take place in fantasy settings, where gamers can use fictional magic and telekinesis powers.

WikiResult.abstract: Augmented reality (AR) is a live direct or indirect view of a physical, real-world environment whose elements are augmented (or supplemented) by computer-generated sensory input such as sound, video, graphics or GPS data. It is related to a more general concept called mediated reality, in which a view of reality is modified (possibly even diminished rather than augmented) by a computer. As a result, the technology functions by enhancing ones current perception of reality. By contrast, virtual reality replaces the real world with a simulated one. Augmentation is conventionally in real-time and in semantic context with environmental elements, such as sports scores on TV during a match. With the help of advanced AR technology (e.g. adding computer vision and object recognition) the information about the surrounding real world of the user becomes interactive and digitally manipulable. Information about the environment and its objects is overlaid on the real world. This information can be virtual or real, e.g. seeing other real sensed or measured information such as electromagnetic radio waves overlaid in exact alignment with where they actually are in space.Augmented reality basically brings out the components of the Digital world into our perceived Real world. Daqri is an company that works on AR products. The best example of AR is their new AR Helmet for contruction workers. This helmet displays essential information about the construction sites to help the workers.
WikiResult.title: Augmented reality

WikiResult.abstract: Smart contracts are computer protocols that facilitate, verify, or enforce the negotiation or performance of a contract, or that make a contractual clause unnecessary. Smart contracts usually also have a user interface and often emulate the logic of contractual clauses. Proponents of smart contracts claim that many kinds of contractual clauses may thus be made partially or fully self-executing, self-enforcing, or both. Smart contracts aim to provide security superior to traditional contract law and to reduce other transaction costs associated with contracting.

WikiResult.title: Visual programming language
WikiResult.summary: In computing, a visual programming language (VPL) is any programming language that lets users create programs by manipulating program elements graphically rather than by specifying them textually. A VPL allows programming with visual expressions, spatial arrangements of text and graphic symbols, used either as elements of syntax or secondary notation. For example, many VPLs (known as dataflow or diagrammatic programming) are based on the idea of "boxes and arrows", where boxes or other screen objects are treated as entities, connected by arrows, lines or arcs which represent relations.

WikiResult.summary: 3D printing, also known as additive manufacturing (AM), refers to various processes used to synthesize a three-dimensional object. In 3D printing, successive layers of material are formed under computer control to create an object. These objects can be of almost any shape or geometry and are produced from a 3D model or other electronic data source. A 3D printer is a type of industrial robot.
WikiResult.abstract: 3D printing, also known as additive manufacturing (AM), refers to various processes used to synthesize a three-dimensional object. In 3D printing, successive layers of material are formed under computer control to create an object. These objects can be of almost any shape or geometry and are produced from a 3D model or other electronic data source. A 3D printer is a type of industrial robot. Futurologists such as Jeremy Rifkin believe that 3D printing signals the beginning of a third industrial revolution, succeeding the production line assembly that dominated manufacturing starting in the late 19th century. Using the power of the Internet, it may eventually be possible to send a blueprint of any product to any place in the world to be replicated by a 3D printer with "elemental inks" capable of being combined into any material substance of any desired form. 3D printing in the term's original sense refers to processes that sequentially deposit material onto a powder bed with inkjet printer heads. More recently, the meaning of the term has expanded to encompass a wider variety of techniques such as extrusion and sintering-based processes. Technical standards generally use the term additive manufacturing for this broader sense.
WikiResult.title: 3D printing

subcategories.Description:
Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) 
 - Commonly known as FDM, which is actually a Stratasys' trademark.
The material in shape of a strand, called filament, is extruded by a heated head typically controlled in y and x direction. This is by far the most well-known 3D-print technology. Surface finish, strength, precision etc. vary a depending on the machine quality and the users ability to adjust and replace components.
Synonyms: Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM), Plastic Jet Printing (PJP)

Binder Jetting (BJ) 
Powder material (gypsum or plastic) is clued together with a binder extruded through print heads. These printers are often able to print in colours and the mechanism is very simple so they can be opened to any material. Parts are often fragile but can be strengthened with epoxy or similar.

Selective Laser Sintering (SLS)
Plastic powder is melted together by a CO2 laser. Mirrors control the laser spot in Y and X direction. By scanning the powder surface several times a solid durable part is build up layer by layer. SLS is the only (or one of few) 3D print technologies that have absolutely no need for support structure while building durable parts. This allow the user to manufacture with completely free geometry.

Stereolithography (SLA)
The part is built on a platform submerged in liquid photopolymer resin. The resin is exposed to a UV-laser where parts are build. SLA is known for its high level of detail, precision and smooth surface.
Synonyms: CLIP, SGC,

Laminated Object Manufacturing (LOM)
Layers of paper, plastic or metal foil is glued together and cut by a knife or laser. This technology is not widely used though it is quite simple, mainly due to limited geometrical freedom - compared to other types of 3D printers.
Synonyms: Selective Deposition Laminiation (SDL)

Laser Melting (LM)
A fiber laser beam is controlled in Y and X direction by mirrors (scanning). This generates a melt pool (typically of 200 m), which micro welds fine metal powder fully together, achieving mechanical properties comparable with traditional machined parts.
Synonyms: Selective Laser Melting (SLM), Direct Metal Laser Sintering (DMLS), Laser Cusing

Cladding
Cladding is combining the basics of FDM in term of a moving print head with LM in term of strength. The print head is usually moved in multiple dimensions e.g. combined with a 5-axis cnc or on a robot arm. The 5 axis CNC platform allow alternately machining and fabrication and the robot arm allow manufacturing of extraordinary large parts. Both techniques enables deposition in all direction and is not restricted to solely Z-direction. The printhead deposits melted material on a solidified surface. The feedstock can be either metal wire or powder, which is melted by an electronic beam or a laser.
Synonyms: Laser Cladding, Directed Energy Deposition (DED), Laser Metal Deposition, Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS)

Material Jetting (MJ)
For this technology, all material is extruded from a printhead, in contrast to BJ, but stil similar with a injektion print head.

trends.Name: Desktop manufacturing
trends.Description: # Desktop Manufacturing Desktop Manufacturing relates to machines usually associated with size ranging from a normal inkjet 2D-printer to maximum 1x1x1 meter and with a price range from 05000 . However, sometimes the production depends on further processes in additional machines, which in total does not fit the desktop anymore. This size of machines is available for most digital tools for manufacturing like 3D printing, Laser cutting and CNC routing. For some makers and enterprises the ideal machine is reliable and cannot be fiddled with, a so-called out-of-the-box machine (3D printers like UP3D UP Plus 2 and CraftUnique CraftBot see picture below) and for others, it needs to be completely open and adjustable in any way even by building it themselves like the RepRap. This printer is a low budget project for the real hardware-software enthusiast. The idea is to make a machine that can reproduce itself. All brackets and joints have been printed with another 3D-printer. It comes in many shapes and sizes. ## Gap is closing in the years to come The gap between more expensive machines for manufacturing and cheaper desktop models is closing. Part quality regarding surface finish, mechanical properties, resolution and reliability of the printer is equal to many of the bigger and professional machines within many technologies like laser cutters and 3D printers like FDM and SLA technologies. In the next year or so, competition between desktop 3D printers and industrial systems will increase as the capabilities of the desktop systems continue to grow5 E.g. we already see printers in this market with features to recognise the material and adjust the print settings automatically. The key enabler for making these machines attractive for makers and small enterprises is the low price range compared to larger and more professional systems. Even though the technology is not on the same level, in many cases it does not justify the 90 times higher price on professional systems.6 Another advantage making these machines attractive for enterprises is the wide range of materials available on the market. With the number of machines manufacturers exploding the recent years, so is material manufacturers. For the open desktop 3D printers, material is actually available that is not yet available for the closed professional machines, e.g. soft TPU, metal filled, metal clay, conductive and biodegradable filament. In Wholers report Joris Peels estimate that filament developers and manufacturers could drive the desktop market growth, as they develop material the industrial end users needs. ## Known technology will be cheap and at desktop size Stratasys patent on FDM printing opened in 2009 and since then the market have flooded with FDM-printers. Just recently, the patents on Laser sintering (SLS) and Stereolithography (SLA) opened, so these technologies will soon be available on low budget. This SLS technology is widely used in the enterprise market (print services). These is due to good mechanical properties of the parts. The downside is poor surface roughness due to powder materials. The powder material causes an issue with material handling, when it comes to makers and consumers, as it needs to be handled with personal protection equipment. These machines are already available in desktop size but the price is not below 5000 Euro yet, though this is expected to happen within five years or so. Plastic printers will be more reliable, have slightly better detail and finish, but will also print in several materials in one printer. The materials will be more advances, making it possible to print electrical circuits and combine the materials e.g. rubber-like and rigid plastic. Few machines already have the ability to print a continuous fibre reinforcement into the print, increasing the strength and stiffness several times, addressing the issue with poor mechanical properties in FDM parts. This is likely to pick up, when consumers adapt to the technology and find more applications to this. When more technologies have accessed the consumer market, new exciting materials will follow e.g. Metals and ceramics in liquid SLA material.7 In approximately five years, ongoing projects about extruding metals with a desktop printer will be finished. June 2016 a metal printer (aluminium) with droplets had its debut. In the beginning, this will only be available for the enterprise. Other projects related to this, e.g. using electroplating techniques for printing will also be close to market techniques for printing will also be close to market. ## Machines are getting smaller and smarter Better, cheaper and more reliable machines will make digital manufacturing more popular in general in all markets; maker, consumer and enterprise. This will accelerate product development8 and lead to greater mass customisation and distributed manufacturing This could eventually lead to more home manufacturing and thus to more makers. Later on, these makers will be ordinary end users - without the thinking of maker movement but home manufacturing could be as natural as shopping (you shop online and print it yourself). Technologies for 3D-printing which will access the market for makers in few years, like SLA and Poly-jetting (both light polymerization) is now suitable for enterprises. In order to prepare it for hobbyist, issues about material handling must be taken care of. Very fine powder from the SLS and the toxic epoxy liquid from SLA can cause health damage if it is not suitable handled. ## From a makers perspective The increase in numbers of cheap FDM printers, laser cutters and even CNC routers on the market have facilitated huge growth in the maker movement. More technologies that are available, opening up to an even wider range of materials (different surface finishes and mechanical properties) and new design freedom will lead to continues exponential growth9 in the maker movement. When all these machines becomes better and smarter and one does not need to be a real tinkerer or even have technical insight. ## From a consumer perspective For every day consumers the machine will only be useful when it is completely reliable and only the material needs to be refilled. By now, it is completely applicable in homes for making small gadgets with very easy to use machines. When it comes to ease of use machines, the collaboration between Microsoft and MakerBot10 serves a good example on how machines for home manufacturing will soon be plug and print, as we are all used to when printing out a document. One way, this user group is already in contact with the new technology, is through educational systems. One of the largest markets for desktop machines is believed to be in educational institutions.11 3D-printing and other digital tools for manufacturing is already a permanent piece of equipment in the workshop at some public schools and most schools for higher education. Here it facilitates better understanding and acquire skills when teaching STEM12 13 (Science, technology, engineering and mathematics). Eventually this will also lead to more advanced parts in every home. ## From an enterprise perspective This will accelerate with designers increased awareness of the new possibilities with digital tooling facilitated by. Even though it is believed that hundreds of companies produce desktop 3d-printers in this low price range, the majority ends up in enterprises, perhaps as many as 65-75%. Engineering departments and designers have been the largest users.14 Like stated before, this will speed up the pace which products are being developed when small manufacturing machines is wide spread in all engineering departments 15 and make products better and smart with the bigger freedom of design that comes with digital tools for manufacturing. Even though the small desktop machines technology wise will still lag behind larger professional machines at the current time, this trend will by time facilitate, that designers and engineers, will design each product smarter (e.g. more efficient or have tweaked mechanical properties like damping) and consist of fewer parts. E.g. vital and compact parts in high performance applications like turbine engines.16

trends.Name: Personalized manufacturing
trends.Description: # Personalized manufacturing When the end customer is either changing design by choosing a different color, typing a text or designing them-self a product better suiting their needs, they become the co-creator along with original designers. This is already possible on one of the biggest print service platforms like [Shapeways](https://www.shapeways.com/create).Here, one can also upload the new design and let other buy their design in just a few hours, making it very easy for a consumer to shift to designer and entrepreneur very fast. Another approach to personalised manufacturing is either to design your piece in a software intended for your purpose and ask for a price of manufacturing on a network like [3D-hubs](https://www.3dhubs.com/). ## New possibilities but not just perfect This is already happening, but elements that slows things down is e.g. the range of materials and surface quality. Especially the surface finish of 3D printed parts is - without post processing still far from conventional manufactured parts. Another thing that could slow things down is the resistance from established companies with violated intellectual properties on designs being shared on [file repositories](https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2014/01/17/3d-printers-will-soon-change-the-world-if-its-not-strangled-in-a-lawyered-up-world/#3baf31c932a2). Ease of use is critical to mass customization efforts. Big companies have previously failed to succeed with [mass customisation](https://techcrunch.com/2014/11/11/the-rise-of-online-customization/) because of complex and costly operations. With digital manufacturing tools at an affordable price, things a changing but it is still essential that the user is required an effort as little as possible. ## From a makers perspective In relation to personalised design, makers is far ahead of enterprise and consumer in terms of variation and projects. Many makers make stuff they could buy as mass produced cheaper, just to give it a personal touch. Sometimes they find the product lacking, needs to [tweak](https://www.tinkerforge.com/en/doc/Kits/HardwareHacking/ForBeginners.html) it a little bit, and thereby [improves](https://www.defcon.org/images/defcon-12/dc-12-presentations/Fullam/dc-12-fullam.pdf) it, to fulfil their specific needs. ## From a consumer perspective Customisation, designing, tweaking etc. is already very familiar terms for most makers a part of the movements DNA but this is still to be fully adapted by the everyday consumer. When it does, it will blur out the lines between consumer and maker. This could be accelerated by technologies like 3D-scanners in everyday devices we surround our self with like smart phones. At present, most makers tend to be male, but this could change when consumers start to co-create their every day-gods. Because of different shopping behaviours of men and women, customisation seems more appealing to women. Women tend to be more invested in the shopping experience, while men just want to buy a specific item and get out. [techcrunch](https://techcrunch.com/2014/11/11/the-rise-of-online-customization/) ## From an enterprise perspective We already see a lot of small start-ups but also major brands branding them by mass customisation. The majority of established brands is doing it as a part of a campaign but smaller companies build their business on this approach of personal design. This can lead to higher prices a customers are willing to pay more but more important it also leads to more loyal to company, better products, knowing their customers [needs](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/erik-eliason/mass-customization_b_1313875.html). Nevertheless, by time this also requires companies to develop and adapt their business model. This is becoming a sales parameter that, so far, only few in each business area is taking advantage of and uses as a sales parameter. When customers get used to having several options in design or do it them self, this will be expected in many industries. The distribution of digital tools for manufacturing along with this trend evolving, the global supply is changing. [more](http://converge.xyz/3d-printing-personalized-manufacturing/) [more](https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/ch/Documents/consumer-business/ch-en-consumer-business-made-to-order-consumer-review.pdf) Today this market is dominated by medical devises like dental and body implants, prosthetic and hearing [aids](http://blog.widex.com/post/81668566088/ite-hearing-aids-how-they-work). Most of this is in specialised larger enterprises but small starts-ups specialise in personalised helping devices to.

trends.Name: Distributed manufacturing
trends.Description:
# Distributed manufacturing 
Distributed manufacturing refers to a decentralized production by either enterprises or makers and consumers. This is normally associated with digital manufacturing tools, like 3D printers, laser cutters, CNC routers among others, capable of making tangible objects from digital files. Manufacturing with these machines can be organized in a network e.g. a platform like 3D-hubs17, enabling customers to find a local manufacturing service. Consumers can fabricate in their own home, components designed by themselves or found online, or order it in the nearby fabrication service18 (could soon be at the supermarket19). 

Until now, machines for digital manufacturing have required several steps in the process from finished 3D model to start manufacturing like file converting, error fixing, slicing and other depending on the system, which is all a part of the file preparation. With the Windows 3D Builder App, the 3D printer is connected straight to the computer and is used completely like a normal inkjet printer with no further actions (as you would properly already expect it to do some day). 

## Designed and produced locally 
For some time, the future look out for distributed manufacturing and its effects have been the called the biggest thread to the shipping industry20 21. Since then the hype about e.g. 3D printing have been replaced with a more relaxed view, as Sebastiaan Scholte, CEO Jan De Rijk, says; maybe (it will) revolutionize traditional manufacturing, but going to enhance traditional manufacturing. 22 

## Manufacturing moves closer to the house  but not inside yet 
In the next few years, new technologies for desktop manufacturing will be available with a wider range of materials and more durability than today. Materials for widely used technologies is developing all the time. Regarding 3D print, part quality and properties will still be far from traditional manufacturing e.g. injection moulding, so it will still mainly be for gadgets, toys, small repairs. For the makers the new affordable technologies like DLP and SLS, will have a larger impact and give maker developers opportunities with even more design freedom and higher detail and tolerances. When these machines fully reaches the market, it could catalyse the every day consumers interest in 3D print or just the ability to print out a tangible piece at home.  

In the nearby future, many print services like Shapeways and iMaterialise will emerge, and they will be more widespread and local. Many smaller print services already exist and are now teaming up with the package delivery services like UPS.23 

The distributed manufacturing is , made possible by continuing price reduction24 and at the same time advancing machine capabilities, is also beneficial for developing countries, where residents in rural areas is a long way from advances technology, medical help and sometimes reliable power25. Several organisations26 is facilitating and creating awareness in these areas on life changing tools like prosthetics made with a FDM printer. The same places 

also benefits from manufacturing of simple replacement parts, where they would normally have to travel the whole day to a bigger city for more expensive parts.27 28 

## 3.3.3. Consumers will have it their  way 
New materials for printers are surfacing at an even higher pace than the printers are, constantly giving the users new designs and techniques to explore all the time. The urge for products specially designed by one self or available in limited editions etc., is a general trend in the society. (mass customisation)29 30 Erik Eliason express: Consumers expect it their way. And Every Customer is Their Own Market.31 Digital tools for fabrication makes this much easier to achieve, with consumers being able to manufacture by them self or nearby. 

Partly due to quality of the consumer-affordable machines output and especially due to their non-existing ability to print in several materials, it will take a long time before consumers just print their new coffee machine, shaver or smartphone. That being said, an enormous amount of technologies is under development right now, and by time they will merge (PCB and electronics printing)32 and compile all the unique features each technology have today and thereby one day satisfy the everyday consumers expectations and needs at an affordable prize. The idea of printing 

the finished product with its electronics might not be too far out the future. A few companies is already selling printers and desktop printers with ability to print in multi-material able to print a PCB circuit. 

Print services will still emerge  in the next five and amazons trucks is going to print on its way to the customer33. Later these will likely close, when consumers get their own multi-material printer, serving their entire needs. Analytics estimate that this market will grove slow in the early years but accelerate after 2020 into a 65 billion euro industry.34 

## Materials and quality is slowing the movement down 
As the digital tools nearby product developers, designers and end user customers enables possibilities that will change the global supply chain, it is still a technology developing each day. Elements that slows things down is e.g. the range of materials and surface quality. Especially the surface finish of 3D printed parts is - without post processing  still far from conventional manufactured parts. 

Another thing that could slow things down is the resistance from established companies with violated intellectual properties on designs being shared on file repositories.35 36 

## From a makers perspective 
When using conventional manufacturing methods you have to know a great deal about each technique to make sure your design compile with that. When using 3D-printing you can get started with no knowledge at all. This is putting the manufacturing back in the hands of everyday users. 

## From a consumers perspective 
Maybe not in 2 years but later on, every consumer would probably find it normal to order ones gadget and pick it up a few hours later in the local shop or print it out them self. The end user could either manufacture it at home, order it at the nearby print service or have it delivered with a truck producing the part on its way. 

## From an enterprise perspective 
Having a tool for digital manufacturing nearby results in faster and cheaper product development, reducing the cost of entry into markets, makes it a lot easier to start new business and for businesses to try out new designs with little risk related to investments in manufacturing tools. 37  

Decentralised manufacturing may change the balance in global economy. Part of the global production may shift back to wealthy countries, leading to decreased shipping volumes of goods between Asia and other continents, at the same time increasing the shipping volumes of raw materials between continents.38 This is of cause a threat to shipping industries but it also creates opportunities. 

In some industries, minimising waiting time for replacements parts, causing expensive downtime, is crucial. The potential for decentralised manufacturing is enormous. Industries like marine and aerospace see very interesting possibilities in printing parts locally around the world very fast and not having huge expenses on inventories; if a carrier can have a spare part made in every larger airport, harbour or even on the ship, they can reduce downtime and save millions. To achieve this kind of setup, it takes years and a lot of money invested in process control, classification, verification and part quality control/assessment. With this in place, it will immediately effect the whole manufacturing industry. 

These possibilities is also appealing to hospitals where waiting time can cause more severe damage than money loss.39 

The final example is probably not for everyone, but instead of bringing all construction materials to the moon when you want to build a space station there, bring a 3D printer and use the lunar sand as material.

trends.Name: Open Design / Open Hardware
trends.Description:
# Open source hardware and open design 
Opensource.com, the online community to learn more about how the open source way is improving technologies, education, business, government, etc, states that: "Open hardware," or "open source hardware," refers to the design specifications of a physical object which are licensed in such a way that said object can be studied, modified, created, and distributed by anyone. So "Open hardware" is a set of design principles and legal practices, not a specific type of object. The term can therefore refer to any number of objectslike automobiles, chairs, computers, robots, or even houses."   

On the other hand, there's also the open source softwatare or code. It works under the same pinciples of the open hardware but aplied to code like: chematics, blueprints, logic designs, Computer Aided Design (CAD) drawings or files, etc. So users can access the technology and modify it, fix it, improve it and share it again with the community. 

So, as stated in Opensource.com: "Essentially, open hardware eliminates common roadblocks to the design and manufacture of physical goods; it provides as many people as possible the ability to construct, remix, and share their knowledge of hardware design and function." As open source design does the same with code. 

## New licenses and Business models 
Open hardware gives a new way to see licenses and business models for companies. Not all the companies that work with open source hardware and design work under the same agreements or licence condition. Some examples, like Arduino (case study of this project) has registered its name as a trademark so others can use their designs, but can't use the Arduino name on them. But RepRap, the 3D printer company, releases all its designs under a free software license: the GNU General Public License. Others like littleBits implements open-source business models by making the design files available for the circuit designs in each littleBits module, in accordance with the CERN Open Hardware License Version 1.2.88 

Opensource.com clarifies that: "All open hardware must be accompanied by documentation, including design files and source code. In addition, the license governing the reproduction of open hardware must allow modification and distribution of those design files in a way that allows others to easily obtain them. This makes possible  and even encourages  studying, troubleshooting, modifying, and improving open hardware. If a piece of open hardware incorporates software of any kind, then that software should generally be released under an approved open source license. Alternatively, the open hardware's interfaces should be documented in a way that makes writing open source software for the hardware as easy as possible.Essentially, open hardware is all about making the object as easy to remix and reproduce as possible. Closed hardware uses obfuscation and patent law to make the recreation of the objects as difficult as possible, usually to ensure vendor lock-in in a supply line that doesn't involve hobbyists and makers or other competitors." 

Most of these projects are founded with crowfunding campaings on Kickstarter, Indiegogo or Crowdsupply, the specialized website for crowdfunding open hardware projects. 

## Working Groups
The Open Design + Hardware (OD+H) Working Group is a global network of makers, academics, designers and openness advocates who are working to build a community of practice around open design and hardware across paradigms, from product design to architecture to digital design and physical art. 

OD+H Members aim to provide a central point of reference for the development of OD+H in both theory and in practice. They run workshops, deliver lectures, engage in hands-on collaborative projects and training initiatives, develop domain-specific guides, curate open collections and host events around the world. We also provide a place for discussion amongst practitioners interested in finding new solutions for a wide range of related issues including intellectual property, law, society, free culture and the commons. 


The OD+H Working Group was founded in 2012 with the help of the Open Knowledge Foundation (UK) and Aalto University Media Factory (Finland). Notable collaborations in the groups first year have included hosting an Open Design, Hardware and Fabrication track at the Open Knowledge Festival 2012 in Helsinki, releasing v0.1 of the new Open Design Definition through Github and a series of interactive workshops across Europe, helping support the launch of the first-ever Public Domain Remix competition in France and delivering keynotes about the correlations between design, openness and hardware at LibreGraphics Meeting 2013 in Madrid and at FREE CITY 2012 in Tallinn. 

The first project they introduced as a group was the Open Design Definition v0.1 on Github in 2012, the first draft of a community-driven thought project to explore a crucial and missing step towards developing our thoughts about the field. They started by integrating the work of several existing definitions for inspiration in this process, including the first Open Design definition drafted in 2000, the Open Design Manifesto, the Open Design page on Wikipedia and the Open Hardware definition. In its current state, they realised, the linguistics of the word design include many potential meanings and applications. To quote a much-used phrase, to design is to design a design to produce a design. As a group, they aimed to develop this missing definition through inclusive and collaborative methods rooted in public discussion, workshopping and sharing different understandings of the field to ensure such a definition would adequately cover all the potential meanings and applications of design. 


Moreover, we wanted the product of this collaboration to be developed and owned by a wide community of people interested in open design. The result was the first release of The Open Design Definition in early 2013 on Github, and this definition is still evolving through further discussion. Below is a comic outlining the initial steps of this process. 

Designer revisions on the Github repo continue today, and we periodically organise Github for Designers tutorials around the world to help continue this work abroad. Interested in being a part of this project? Please email us to get started. 

## Open source hardware and design for makers
Open hardware is facilitating STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) in primary and secondary schools, universities and post-graduate schools, making it much easier to find a project to contribute to or as instructions to start a building a copy in the school. This is also the case for individual citizens, but for some time it must be considered for the innovators / early adaptors as this requires a lot of tinkering and technical insight.

trends.Name: Immersive interaction
trends.Description: # Immersive Interaction ## Virtual Reality & Augmented Reality In recent years, we have seen the adoption of mobile computing with mobile phones and tablets to a degree where it overtook the use of the traditional laptop/PC at an unexpected pace. Early 2017 Android overtook Windows as the most used Operating System to browse the Web . a sign that consumers have definitely changed the way how we connect online. The mobility aspect has introduced all kinds of new services (e.g. location based services) and has changed how, when and where we communicate and consume. One thing that has remained the same mostly of the years that we still mostly interact with screens. Once we interact with a screen we are slightly removed from the actual reality. It has fascinated researchers for many years what would happen if we could interact differently with computers. One of the first pioneers in this field was Morton Heilig. In 1962 he build the Sensorama (Figure 15), an experiment in user interaction that uses not only sight, but also touch, sound, smell and air. In the following years most innovations didnt leave the laboratory. The name Virtual Reality was introduced in 1987, followed by Augmented Reality in 1990. Virtually Reality is a technology that uses headset to project an immersive 3D environment for the user. In order to do so, the headset needs to track the position and orientation of the person and most often needs a powerful computer to generate the images. For the user it feels like he or she is in a completely different environment. Augmented Reality on the other hand, uses an overlay to project graphics over the actual environment. This requires less graphical resources, but most often needs a more advanced mapping system to localize the position of the use in relation to his or her surroundings. Compared to Virtual Reality, the adoption and technical readiness level of Augmented Reality is still behind, but compared to the mouse that was invented in the same time period Virtual- and Augmented reality both had a rough and slow start. So will that change now with the recent introduction of commercial products like the Oculus Rift, HTC Vive and the Microsoft HoloLens? Or even more important why would we want use these devices at all? ## Military and Industry take the lead In general you could say that Virtual Reality with its ability to generate complete new environment is especially useful for gaming and training settings. For years the army is using games like Virtual Battlespace92 to train its soldiers to collaborate, the next step is a realistic VR environment 93 with full battle simulations. The industry is currently discovering the use of Virtual Reality for training situations as well. A complete job floor could be generated within a VR experience for training an operator how to do his or her job. Some of the VR headsets like the HTC Vive are accompanied by wireless controllers to track all hand movements to really operate machines or logistic tasks. Although the headsets have really improved over these last years, people can still experience motion sickness when using VR. This VR motion sickness94 could be a barrier for the effectiveness of longer training sessions Because Augmented Reality really relies on the environment of the user, the typical use cases of AR can be expected on the actual job floor itself. An operator could get work instructions for repairing or assembling tasks, he or she could be presented with information and visualisation overlays that would not have been available or using remote support an expert could give instructions while virtually looking over his shoulder. Many of these applications are currently being piloted by companies like Volkswagen, Siemens and Boeing and if found useful could be expected to be used on a broader scale in the coming years. ## Augmented Reality for makers One of the reasons that AR headsets have not been so widely used within the maker scene is probably the price tag of the headsets. The most popular AR headset at this moment, the Microsoft HoloLens, has a price tag of $3.000. Another issue with current generation is that the window of overlay is often too small. This limited field-of view is in stark contrast with the VR experience. But already companies have announced cheaper headsets with a larger field-of-view, so we can expect prices to lower, making AR also affordable for consumers. and its limited How would makers use VR and AR? Education, training and collaboration are probably among the first domains to be explored. There are already 3D design tools in Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality. With a couple of simple hand gestures you can build your 3D models with the HoloLens in an app called HoloStudio95. An education use case could be the following: makers could be assisted with their tools and activities while having someone else virtually sitting next to them giving suggestions or instructions. That someone else could be a friend or expert that is actually somewhere else or it could be a virtual assistant with the knowledge of the tools and specific thing you want to make. This could work for assembling a 3D printer, soldering sensors on an Arduino microcontroller or even building with Lego.

trends.Name: Data Analysis & Artificial Intelligence
trends.Description: # Data analytics With the gaining popularity of IoT and wireless sensor networks that will be monitoring our health, cities, industries and houses a lot more sensor data is expected to be gathered over the next decennia. But the goal of using the Internet of Things most often is not to gather data, but to make better decisions. Better said: to assist people in making better decisions. Gartner's analytics maturity model identified four different types of analytics: descriptive, diagnostic, predictive and prescriptive. Descriptive and diagnostic analytics help to understand what is happening and why this is happening. Predictive and prescriptive analytics are used to see what is going to happen and how to influence are needed to predict what is going to happen or how too make it happen. In working with IoT and 'big data' most initiatives still would be happy to fully utilize the first two types of analytics. The technical challenges in data collection and storage are sometimes already overwhelming. ## Data handling for IoT Already many different big data solutions are surfacing to collect, store and analyze this data. Cloud computing companies are offering a wide range of solutions for connecting devices, collecting data, storage, analyzing and visualization of data. At the same time many companies share and collaborate on open source software to handle this IoT data. The Apache Software Foundation for example supports many open source initiatives like Apache Hadoop , a framework for storing big data, Apache Spark , a framework to facilitate large-scale data processing, and Apache Zeppelin a tool for interactive analytics. It is good to note that gathering data is almost never the real goal in working with IoT. The data is in the end needed to make decisions. Decisions made by humans or decisions made in an automated control loop. Traditionally businesses would rely on spreadsheets, database queries, custom digital dashboard and Business Intelligence tools like Tableau and Qlik. But most of these applications are not ready for the potential scale of the amount of data they need to handle in large scale IoT setups. One approach to handle this problem is to use computing clusters with scalable databases and analytics platforms, like Hadoop and Spark. These platforms are able to distribute storage and calculations over multiple machines (thousands, if needed). This requires a different way of programming, but already many programming languages and Business Intelligence tools are able to connect to these computing clusters. GPU-accelerated computing is another way to accelerate applications that need to handle large calculations. A GPU (graphics processing unit) is a processor that is very good in handling multiple tasks at the same time, with relative low energy consumption. Companies like MapD are introducing new databases and analytics platforms that leverage GPU-accelerated computing and at the same promising a scalable architecture. This combination has the potential to really unlock the promise of IoT data analytics. ## Artificial Intelligence For really learn from the acquired data (starting with diagnostic analytics) typically people turn to Artificial intelligence (AI), a subfield of computer science that studies intelligence exhibited by machines. The field has developed in close relationship with research on neuronetworks, mathematics, linguistics, sociology and psychology. Artificial intelligence is often implemented as a machine or a computer program that is able to recreate intelligent behavior (usually only attributed to human mind) such as accomplishing a complex goal. The definition of artificial is evolving as it gets more and more capable over time but it usually refers to the ability to mimic human like intelligent behavior such as learning and problem solving. A weak AI is geared toward a specific task while a strong or full AI would attempt to solve all problems that a human brain can (reason, language, creativity). Although there is much debate on properly coining the terminology what is intelligence and how to quantify it, it is currently accepted that all AIs up to date and are weak AIs. And this is mostly likely to be the case in the next 2 years. An AI is a device (agent) that captures information about its environment through various means (physical or virtual sensors) and responds to this information in a perception action cycle. The actions taken by the agent maximize the chances of success towards a specific goal. The last few years have seen a number of weak AIs performing better at specific tasks than humans. A library of weak AIs that outperform humans at various tasks is currently being rapidly developed. Full AI might emerge in a bit longer time frame (2 to 5 years) but it has the potential to outperform humans in all aspects. ## AI will automate and outperform Any job that can be automated will be automated. This is both a threat and an opportunity as it will lead to people working on more creative tasks, therefore to a rise in the maker movement. Automation of task should allow to free up time for humans to work on more advances tasks that the AI cannot achieve (mostly creative tasks) yet and raise the value of what is being produced. Once Strong AI (or full AI) becomes available it has the potential to outperform humans in all possible aspects. Humanity will not be able to control AIs for their own purpose and the saying if you cannot beat them, join them will become more than relevant. Technologies like the neurolink will become key for human to be able to enhance themselves and take full advantage of the power of those AI , by connecting or even merging with them. ## Will humans stay in control? AI comes with many very real threats. In the next 2 years, it will primarily threaten jobs. Automation usually affected the most repetitive jobs not requiring high level of education, but with the arrival of machine learning AI, all type of jobs having a repetitive aspect are now threatened. For example a specialist eye doctor can train more than 10 years to be able to recognize specific eye sickness, only one or few doctors will be needed to train an AI to do this task and collecting enough data. Such AI can quickly outperform any human to this specific task. Ethical issues of how undirected intelligence can be harmful as well as lost jobs are the current main concerns. AI is one of the most controversial fields and has many top researchers worried about a future where a superintelligence becomes more intelligent than any human. Making AI safe and controllable is considered as important as further developing the technology. You could imagine that AI becomes highly regulated to insure that humans stay in control as long as possible. The difficulty usually comes when AI start designing the next generation of AI, as it will reach a moment where this task will become fully automated to a level out of human understanding. Each generation of new AI could come faster than the precedent one and be much more intelligent every time. This exponential growth seems impossible to control for humans. It is usually referred to as the technological singularity. The threat being that super intelligence could take control of robots and the faith of humanity will then rely on them. They could decide to help humanity, co-exist with it, stay hidden and spy on it, control it, eliminate it, or could be not interested at all in humanity and pursue other goals elsewhere.

trends.Name: Maker Education Programs
trends.Description:
# Maker Education Programs

Maker Education is a term coined by Dale Dougherty in 2013  that is closely associated with STEM learning, is an approach to problem-based and project-based learning that relies upon hands-on, often collaborative, learning experiences as a method for solving authentic problems.
As stated before, people who participate in making often call themselves "makers"  of the Maker movement and develop their projects in Makerspaces, Fab Labs, or development studios which emphasize prototyping and the repurposing of found objects in service of creating new inventions or innovations. Culturally, this kind of spaces are, both inside and outside of schools, are associated with collaboration and the free flow of ideas.
In schools, maker education stresses the importance of learner-driven experience, interdisciplinary learning, peer-to-peer teaching, iteration, and the notion of "failing forward," or the idea that mistake-based learning is crucial to the learning process and eventual success of a project.
Maker Education is an offshoot of the Maker Movement, which Time Magazine described as ""the umbrella term for independent innovators, designers and tinkerers. A convergence of computer hackers and traditional artisans, the niche is established enough to have its own magazine, Make, as well as hands-on Maker Faires that are catnip for DIYers who used to toil in solitude."" Dale Dougherty, founder of the Maker Faire and Make magazine, called in his 2011 TED Talk for making to be embraced in education, as students are the new generation of makers.

### Maker Education best practice: Fab Academy.
Fab Labs are structured in a network and they propose the Fab Academy program as a Maker Educational program. On the other hand, Makerspaces haven't not organized a global Maker Educational program yet. So, as in many other spaces and development studios the Maker educational offer sticks to workshops about "maker-related" topics (or just the ones that the community is interested in). This program generates a lot of interchange between students from different fields. This makes that new ideas and solutions emerge from that mix of knowledge, needs and networking. In addition, the hands-on learning makes students very active and involved.

The Fab Academy teaches principles and applications of digital fabrication. It was developed to teach hands-on skills in fab labs, which began as an outreach project from MITs Center for Bits and Atoms, and has grown into a global network of more than 500 labs. Fab Academy instruction is based on MITs popular rapid-prototyping course How To Make (almost) Anything, both taught by Prof. Neil Gershenfeld.


### How to Make (Almost) Anything in a distributed education platform all over the world
Fab Academy offers a distributed rather than distance educational model: students learn in local workgroups, with peers, mentors, and machines, which are then connected globally by content sharing and video for interactive classes. The individual labs are supported and supervised regionally by supernode sites with more advanced capabilities, expertise, and inventories.
Each lab that participates in the Fab Academy program is part of a global Fab Lab / Fab Academy network. The local branches of the Fab Academy work with other participating Fab Labs and experts from around the world via a distributed educational model where the local fab lab pool the knowledge to provide a unique educational experience.
List of Fab Labs running Fab Academy program: http://fabacademy.org/2017-nodes-supernodes/
Fab Academy students view and participate in global lectures broadcast from MIT on Wednesdays at 9:00 am  12:00 pm EST. The lectures are recorded and available to students throughout the semester. In addition to the lectures, there are two lab days each week where students have access the digital fabrication equipment and personal help with projects.
Fab Academy faculty, who are leaders in their respective fields provide global video lectures, supervise academic content, and guide research. Hands-on instruction in the labs is provided by instructors who supervise and evaluate Certificates, develop and disseminate instructional material, and assist with projects.

### Fab Academy Contents
Just as communications and computation went from analog to digital, resulting in PCs and the Internet, the
digitization of fabrication is leading to personal fabricators that will allow anyone to make almost anything,
anywhere. The development of digital fabrication is based on creating codes that dont just describe things, they are
things, much as proteins are coded in molecular biology. This research roadmap is ultimately aiming at a Star Trekstyle replicator, but prototype versions of these capabilities are already available in field fab labs.
At the Fab Academy, students learn how to envision, prototype and document their ideas through many hours of
hands-on experience with digital fabrication tools. They learn a variety of code formats and turn them into physical objects. The Fab Academy is a fast paced, hands-on learning experience where students plan and execute a new project each week. Each individual documents their progress for each project, resulting in a personal portfolio of technical accomplishments. Students at the Fab Academy learn:

* How to use a Fab Labs digital fabrication tools for rapid prototyping:
    * Epilog Mini Lasercutter
    * Roland MDX-20 Milling Machine
    * 3D printer
    * Roland CAMM-1 Servo GX-24 Desktop Vinyl Cutter
    * ShopBot CNC Router
* Electronics design and production by producing circuit boards using a variety of sensors and output devices.
* How to program AVR microcontrollers on the boards they have produced.
* Molding and casting
* 3D scanning and printing

The diploma combines 19 certificates provide familiarity with technical options and capabilities, hands-on experience, and direction for further study. The certificates are:
* Digital fabrication principles and practices  1 week 
* Computer-aided design, manufacturing, and modeling  1 week 
* Computer-controlled cutting  1 week 
* Electronics design and production  2 weeks 
* Computer-controlled machining  1 week 
* Embedded programming  1 week 
* 3D molding and casting  1 week 
* 3D scanning and printing  1 week 
* Sensors, actuators, and displays  2 weeks 
* Interface and application programming  1 week 
* Embedded networking and communications  1 week 
* Machine design  2 weeks 
* Digital fabrication applications and implications  1 week 
* Invention, intellectual property, and business models  1 week 
* Digital fabrication project development  2 weeks 

### Is Maker Education, not making
Though Maker Education has been embraced by thousands of schools, there has also emerged criticism of the movement.
The Critical Theory of Maker Education asserts that Maker Education curriculum and pedagogy necessarily aligns itself with the greater educational imperative (as described in the Critical Pedagogy Primer) that ""questions of democracy and justice cannot be separated from the most fundamental features of teaching and learning"" (Kincheloe, Joe L. (2008). Critical Pedagogy. Peter Lang Primer. p. 5. ISBN 978-0-8204-7262-1.). Foundational Critical Theorists like Paulo Freire in his seminal work, Pedagogy of the Oppressed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedagogy_of_the_Oppressed), stressed the need for a new relationship between teacher, student, and school, that would cultivate in students radical liberation from the political injustices that oppress them. Maker Education is another avenue by which radical liberation is possible.
In his article A more lovingly made world,(Wark, McKenzie (2013). ""A more lovingly made world"". Cultural Studies Review. 19: 296304) McKenzie Wark of The New School (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_School) writes that the problem with maker culture is that makers dont actually make things, they assemble them. While this experience is satisfying and fun (and Wark does acknowledge the way in which his children are not hemmed in by gender expectations while playing at the Maker Faire), it doesnt teach the underlying principles required for the actual making of functional objects. It also does not, though Chris Anderson and Mark Hatch evoke Marx in their Maker manifestos, map accurately onto an understanding of labor, and certainly not the life of the laborer.
Alessandro Carelli, Massimo Bianchini, and Venanzio Arquilla of the Politecnico di Milano argue that Maker Culture presents a ""maker contradiction"" in which DIY producers in the ""so-called Third Industrial Revolution"" become post-production consumers, further reinforcing hierarchies of social, political, and economic power (Carelli, Alessandro; Massimo Bianchini, and Venanzio Arquilla (2014). ""The 'Makers contradiction.' The shift from a counterculture-driven DIY production to a new form of DIY consumption"". 5th STS Italia Conference A Matter of Design: Making Society through Science and Technology).
Among other critics, Evgeny Morozov, a Belarusian writer and researcher, focuses on the impact, both social and political, of technology. In his article published in The New Yorker, entitled, Making It: Pick up a spot welder and join the revolution,[11: ""Making It"". The New Yorker. Retrieved 2016-12-12.] Morozov criticizes Chris Anderson for confusing the history of the Web with the history of capitalism and ends by speculating about the future of the maker movement, which, on closer examination, is actually speculation on the future of capitalism. He also criticizes companies and organizations that were once committed to open source software for becoming acquired by for-profit companies and embroiled in copyright and trademark lawsuits. Morozov also criticizes the maker movements major contributors financial relationship with DARPA, which made a $10 million grant to support maker education for high school students, and $3.5 million to TechShop to establish new makerspaces.

While Morozov is one of the more vocal critics of Maker Education, he is not the only one. Debbie Chachra, associate professor at Olin College of Engineering, in her article in January 23, 2015 issue of The Atlantic, entitled, Why I Am Not a Maker,[12: Chachra, Debbie. ""Why I Am Not a Maker"". The Atlantic. Retrieved 2016-12-12.] centers her criticism on the social history of who makes things -- and who doesnt. Chachra describes the history of the makers of products as men, rather than those who cared for hearth and home, that is, historically, women. She calls for recognition of the work of the educators, those that analyze and characterize and critique, everyone who fixes things, all the other people who do valuable work with and for others - above all, the caregivers - whose work isnt about something you can put in a box and sell.
Finally, Shirin Vossoughi and Paula K. Hooper of Northwestern University, and Meg Escude of Exploratorium (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploratorium), offer an in-depth look at the ways in which Maker Education reinforces educational inequality. They begin by offering Haitian writer, Edwidge Danticats commentary on making: If you cant afford clothes, but you can make them--make them. You have to work with what you have, especially if you dont have a lot of money. You use creativity, and you use imagination. Vossoughi, Hooper, and Escude make the case that true making is often born from difficult environmental circumstances, and that what local communities once did as part of their daily lives (offering an exchange of skills and knowledge, for example, to help others in need in the community) is now being offered to low-income neighborhoods as an intervention program, promising greater educational equality. They argue that the American Maker highlighted by Dale Dougherty in his 2011 Ted Talk, is symptomatic of the problems associated with American exceptionalism, in that it is grounded in gendered, white, middle-class cultural practices. Not only do Vossoughi, Hooper, and Escude critique maker education as it is currently practiced, they also offer proposed solutions for equity-oriented design of maker experiences which include, critical analyses or educational injustice, historicized approaches to making as cross-cultural activity, explicit attention to pedagogy, and inquiry into the sociopolitical values and purposes of making.

### Maker education is for the general public
Maker education is facilitating and supporting STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) in primary and secondary schools, universities and post-graduate schools. In some areas where STEM is not an integrated part of the schools educational program, fab labs, maker spaces and maker education programs, might be the only way into the world of making for the student. This is also the case for individual citizens, but for some time it must be considered for the innovators / early adaptors.

Dpite these Makeder educational prgrams don't have a closed curriculum, they normally are the door to the "making" world for makers. Normally they start their journey with one of thesse programs that gives them the tools to keep researching and making until they realise their projects. So, we could say that Maker educational progarams are useful for makers, if they are specific on a topic for example, but normally they are more focused on kids or students that could become makers.

trends.Name: Internet of Things Infrastructure & Security
trends.Description:
# Internet of Things Infrastructure & Security

## Smart, intelligent and connected
The world is buzzing around the Internet of Things. Everything is becoming smart, intelligent and connected from cups  that make sure you hydrate intelligently, pets , diapers  and even complete smart cities .  With the rise of popularity of microcontrollers like the Arduino, the Maker Movement seems to become an infinite source of creativity. While not all new connected devices will turn out to be useful or relevant in the long term, this IoT trend has started and is already impacting the way we interact with our houses with products like the Amazon Echo  and smart lightbulbs or how we play sports and exercise with one of many of the  fitness trackers.

Also the industry is embracing this trend with applications across the domain of energy to fully optimize the use of your energy grid, health to monitor our wellness, automotive to enable safe self-driving cars and off course smart manufacturing to optimize production. Cities are looking into IoT to optimize transportation, waste management, safety, etc. Juniper  predicts that the number of connected IoT (Internet of Things) devices, sensors and actuators will reach over 46 billion in 2021. 

## Connectivity for IoT
Although more factors drive the Internet of Things, like the advancements in microcontrollers and artificial intelligence, wireless connectivity is one of the enablers of the Internet of Thigs. Wireless protocols range from short range like Bluetooth, Zigbee, Z-Wave and WiFi to long range technologies like satellite communication and Low-Power Wide-Area Network (LPWAN). Short range wireless are often used in home automation or for personal devices. 
Long range wireless technologies like (LPWAN) have existed for quite a while, but only these last year are being discovered by makers with the popularity of  of LoRa  and SigFox . LPWAN has a limited bandwidth and the devices are only allowed to send a limited number of message each day, but they are very power efficient and can sometimes run for a couple of years on batteries. These features make them ideal for sensor networks, for example to measure air quality or track bicycles.  

LoRa, a LPWAN example,  is interesting because it uses an unlicensed radio spectrum, it allows makers to create their own IoT infrastructure with just a Raspberry Pi  without  the need of a paid subscription from a mobile operator. Initiatives like The Things Network  plan to build a global network infrastructure by providing cheap gateways, open-source firmware and encourage and facilitate their community in building applications with tutorials, YouTube videos and code on GitHub.  

This trend has not been overlooked by the telecom industry, several mobile operators are readying their own LoRa network or focussing on NarrowBand  IoT  (NB-IoT) a licenced alternative that for some mobile operators requires just a software update for their existing infrastructure. On the long term 5G, the next standard for mobile wireless communication, also specifically provides solutions for IoT communication. 

## Will it be safe?
As we are entering the era of Internet of Things, we get surrounded by devices that have access to home or company networks. With several recent incidents, like the attack on internet infrastructure company Dyn , it is clear that these devices can pose a threat not only to the integrity of these networks15 but also to critical internet infrastructures. Not many consumers are aware of these vulnerabilities as they buy their new television, smart light bulb, door lock or fitness bracelet. With many different network and communication protocols, suppliers and products are all competing in the same market. At the same time security has been not been highest priority. With possible severe consequences, experts      urge all stakeholders (manufactures, legislators and users) to come up with regulations and enhance the cybersecurity awareness.

trends.Name: Smart Citizen Sensor Networks
trends.Description: # Smart Citizen Sensor Networks A Smart Citizen Sensor Network is an environmental sensing network most often operating in the public domain. This means that the sensors and their data are connected to each other and they come from citizen sources. Nowadays, citizens use sensing technologies daily, like GPS, videos, etc. combined with the web 2.0 technologies, like social network platforms, P2P computing, etc., so they can participate actively in the network as sensors of the issue they need to gather information and improve. As Ren Post, from Waag Society says about it on the Making Sense project website (http://making-sense.eu/covey-design-smart-citizens-sensor-networks/), "in order to build successful sensor-networks around a certain environmental issue, we need to combine the elements of (1) concern, awareness, and (2) frustration due to lack of data to start the project. But, in order to keep citizens involved, it might be a good idea to present people not just with numbers, but (3) compile these numbers into actionable information." The main purpose of these networks is to generate participatory processes of people in the cities. These participatory processes normally tackle an environmental issue that citizens want to improve connecting data, people and knowledge. ## Creating a Smart Citizen Network with Smart Citizens Kit and Making Sense project Smart Citizen is a platform to generate participatory processes of people in the cities. Connecting data, people and knowledge, the objective of the platform is to serve as a node for building productive and open indicators, and distributed tools, and thereafter the collective construction of the city for its own inhabitants. The Smart Citizen project is based on geolocation, the Internet and free hardware and software for data collection and sharing. It connects people with their environment and their city to create more effective and optimized relationships between resources, technology, communities, services and events in the urban environment. The Smart Citizen platform is a full set of of tools waiting from you to start using them: register to the platform, check the API, download the Android app, get a Kit or contribute to the open-source project. The Smart Citizen Kit is a piece of hardware comprised of a sensor and a data-processing board, a battery and an enclousure. The first board carries sensors that measure air composition (CO and NO2), temperature, humidity, light intensity and sound levels. Once its set up, the device will stream data measured by the sensors over Wi-Fi using the FCC-certified, wireless module on the data-processing board. The devices low power consumption allows for placing it on balconies and windowsills. Power to the device can be provided by a solar panel and/or battery. The Kit is not another black box, it is compatible with Arduino and all the design files are open-source (schematics and firmware). For more detailed hardware specifications visit https://docs.smartcitizen.me/#/start/hardware The project is born within Fab Lab Barcelona at the Institute for Advanced Architecture of Catalonia, both focused centers on the impact of new technologies at different scales of human habitat, from the bits to geography. It also got founded thanks to lovely bakers on Kickstarter (2013) and Goteo (2012). Making Sense is a European funded project that will run for two years between 2015 and 2017. The aim is to explore how open source software, open source hardware, digital maker practices and open design can be effectively used by local communities to fabricate their own sensing tools, make sense of their environments and address pressing environmental problems in air, water, soil and sound pollution. The project will tackle that issues using three strategies. First of all, using open source technologies that gather environmental data with communities across Europe, they will be co-creating sensors & devices that use the Smart Citizen platform to capture environmental data. They will also enable and design platforms for collective sensemaking: testing tools and methodologies for making sense of data in pilots in Amsterdam, Barcelona and Prishtina, and raising awareness of social and environmental issues. The project will also take action by moving on a trajectory from awareness to positive change: with the pilot learnings they will develop the Making Sense toolkit a manual to organise citizen sensing campaigns for positive social change. And a Minimum Viable Open Manifesto to provide other projects and their communities with our own insights to better devise citizen engagement strategies and sustainable action plans. The process is currently open and ongoing and it accepts all contributions from all possible sources to keep on amassing new lessons.
